G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 209C, § 20, this Court retains jurisdiction to modify orders concerning custody and parenting time upon a showing of a material change in circumstances and that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the Child.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, custody orders may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances, and the court must determine whether the requested modification serves the best interests of the child.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, custody orders may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances, and the court must determine whether the requested modification serves the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion is about an initial custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, §10(a), not a modification of an existing custody order. The court explicitly refuses to apply or analyze the ‘substantial change in circumstances’ standard from G.L. c. 209C, §20, noting that the case was not tried as a modification proceeding and that any such argument was waived. Thus, the case does not establish the modification standard described in the proposition, nor tie it to a best-interests analysis in the modification context.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20… and are waived.”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: A proposed relocation by one parent and the associated impacts on the parenting schedule are recognized as a material change in circumstances under Massachusetts law.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas is a relocation/removal case, but it does not address modification standards or the concept of “material change in circumstances.” The opinion sets out the substantive ‘real advantage’/best interests test under G.L. c. 208, § 30 to decide an initial removal request in the divorce judgment, not whether a proposed relocation and parenting-schedule impact constitute a material change justifying modification of an existing order. Thus it is not authority for the specific ‘material change in circumstances’ proposition stated.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that…[a] minor child of divorced parents…shall not…be removed out of this commonwealth…without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders. The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865, 870 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: A proposed relocation by one parent and the associated impacts on the parenting schedule are recognized as a material change in circumstances under Massachusetts law.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The opinion does recognize that a material and substantial change in circumstances is required for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and it identifies the custodial parent’s remarriage (and resulting desire to move) as such a change. However, the case does not state or analyze that a proposed relocation and its impact on the parenting schedule, in and of themselves, constitute a material change. The discussion of material change is focused specifically on the post‑divorce remarriage, not on relocation or parenting-time impacts generally, so it does not support the broader proposition claimed.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28… ‘[T]he court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment… provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred….’ Changed circumstances are those that occur subsequent to the judgment of divorce… In the present case, the mother’s marriage is plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances occurring subsequent to the date of divorce.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: The best interests of the Child focus on maintaining her stability, continuity, and emotional and physical wellbeing.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The court explicitly frames custody determinations around the children’s “best interests,” “happiness,” “welfare,” and “probable future,” and then emphasizes the importance of minimizing disruption, maintaining the primary nurturing relationship, and fostering a healthy environment for their growth and development. This directly reflects a focus on the child’s stability, continuity of care, and emotional and physical well‑being, consistent with the claimed proposition.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… ‘the happiness and the welfare of the children should be the controlling consideration. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the children in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future…’ … The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.”

Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766-6.proposition: The best interests of the Child focus on maintaining her stability, continuity, and emotional and physical wellbeing.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766-6.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the "welfare" and "best interests" of the child in the context of parental fitness and state intervention, but it does not articulate a best-interests standard framed specifically in terms of maintaining stability, continuity, or emotional and physical wellbeing. Those concepts appear indirectly (e.g., references to harm from separation and need for stability), yet the case’s focus is on the parental-unfitness standard and the limits on removing a child from a natural parent, not on defining best interests as centered on stability and continuity. Thus, it only indirectly touches on the proposition and does not clearly establish it as a governing principle.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766-6.relevant_excerpt: “[A]t common law it was presumed that a child’s welfare is best served in the care and custody of its parents, but that is not the case if the parents ‘have grievous shortcomings or handicaps that would put the child’s welfare in the family milieu much at hazard’ or ‘[if] some factor such as lengthy separation and a corresponding growth in the ties between the child and the prospective adoptive parents [or custodian] indicate[s] that the child would be hurt by being returned to the natural parents.’”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 261 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Where the current parenting arrangement would cause unnecessary stress and disruption to the Child’s schooling, routines, and relationships, modification is warranted under Massachusetts law.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The case does not state that modification is warranted merely because the current parenting arrangement would cause stress or disruption to the child’s schooling, routines, or relationships. Instead, it reiterates that a modification of custody under G.L. c. 208, § 28 requires a material and substantial change in circumstances of sufficient magnitude to affect the child’s welfare, and it reverses a custody modification that was based largely on relocation and court-imposed temporary changes. The opinion also warns that uprooting a child should occur only for compelling reasons, but never articulates the specific rule claimed in the proposition.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ … ‘The uprooting of a child … should be done only for compelling reasons.’”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012.proposition: Where the current parenting arrangement would cause unnecessary stress and disruption to the Child’s schooling, routines, and relationships, modification is warranted under Massachusetts law.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012.support_reasoning: The case discusses initial custody determinations and best-interests analysis, not modification of an existing custody or parenting plan. While the court does consider stability, living circumstances, and potential harm from moves and disrupted attachments, it does not hold that where a current arrangement causes stress and disruption, modification is warranted; nor does it apply the Massachusetts standard for modification (material and substantial change in circumstances). Thus, the opinion does not provide authority for the specific modification proposition stated.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that, after the move to Oregon, Jill lived in four different residences in less than one year and had ‘no less than five different care providers’… The judge found that a move to Michigan would put Jill ‘in an unfamiliar environment with new caregivers and … medical providers’ while Rose worked ‘extraordinary long hours as a medical resident for the next four years’… There was no abuse of discretion in determining that primary physical custody of Jill should be with the plaintiff.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (20.proposition: As noted in Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (2006), “[t]he paramount concern for a court in deciding a custody case is the well-being of the child.”
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (20.support_reasoning: This opinion repeatedly frames the governing standard in custody/removal disputes as the “best interests” and well-being of the child, and subordinates the parents’ interests—including relocation and constitutional travel concerns—to that child-centered standard. While the exact quoted sentence does not appear verbatim, the reasoning clearly treats the child’s welfare as paramount in deciding custody-related questions, so the proposition is a fair and accurate statement of the principle reflected in the case.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (20.relevant_excerpt: “‘The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985), citing Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 (1976). … ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550, 566 (2000). … The judge here determined that removal would clearly not serve the best interests of the children.”
